translated: Stories of Departed Beings🔽. The Book of the Fives
The Story of the Departed One Who Ate Her Five Children
“You’re thin, ugly, and repulsive,
smelly and putrid.
You’re surrounded by flies.

analyzed: kā nu tvam idha tiṭṭhasi iti
translated: Why are you standing here?”
“Venerable sir, I’m a departed one,
gone to the realm of the dead, to a bad destination.
Having done bad deeds,
I’ve gone from here to the realm of departed beings.
Every five days I give birth to five children,
and then five more the next day.
After giving birth, I eat them,

analyzed: te pi nā honti me ala
translated: but they’re not enough.
I’m burning, I’m smoking,
and my heart is tormented by hunger.
I can’t find any water to drink.
Look at me, fallen into misfortune.”

analyzed: kim nu kāyena vācāya  manasā dukkaṭam kata
translated: “What bad deed was done by body, speech, or mind?
What was the result of what action
that you eat the flesh of your own children?”
“I was jealous of my co-wife,
and I incited her to do bad things.
With a corrupted mind,
I caused her to have an abortion.
Her two-month-old fetus
was nothing but blood.
Her mother, angry with me,
had me brought to the relatives.
He made me swear an oath,

original: paribhāsāpayī ca maṁ.🔽Sāhaṁ ghorañca sapathaṁ,🔽musāvādaṁ abhāsisaṁ;
analyzed: paribhāsa apayī ca ma  sā aham ghoran ca sa patha  musāvādam abhāsisa
translated: and he accused me of lying.
I spoke a terrible lie,
that I had eaten my son’s flesh.
As the result of that deed,
and because of my lie,
I eat my son’s flesh,
smeared with his blood.”

analyzed: pañca putta khāda peti vatthu chaṭṭha
translated: The story of the one who ate her five sons is finished.
